commit_message:
Add playbook for config-download

This playbook generates the inventory and config-download
playbooks from heat stack output.

Change-Id: I307e89f152adce8f091a8904ca32ab13d0dff3c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible refs/changes/38/725238/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- - name: Pre Config download connection: "{{ (tripleo_target_host is defined) | ternary('ssh', 'local') }}" hosts: "{{ tripleo_target_host | default('localhost') }}" remote_user: "{{ tripleo_target_user | default(lookup('env', 'USER')) }}" gather_facts: "{{ (tripleo_target_host is defined) | ternary(true, false) }}" any_errors_fatal: true vars: plan: overcloud-0 ssh_network: ctlplane inflight_validations: false limit_hosts: '' inventory_path: null ssh_user: tripleo-admin skip_tags: '' tasks: - name: Set output_dir fact set_fact: output_dir: "{{ lookup('env', 'HOME')~'/config-download'}}" when: output_dir is not defined - name: Add to skip_tags if inflight validation is not enabled set_fact: skip_tags: '{{ skip_tags.split(",") | union(["opendev-validation"]) | select("match", "^(?!\s*$).+") | list | join(",") }}' when: not inflight_validations - name: Get blacklisted hosts from heat command: |- openstack --os-cloud undercloud stack output show "{{ plan }}" BlacklistedHostnames -c output_value -f value register: blacklist_out - name: Build limit_hosts set_fact: limit_hosts: '{{ (blacklist_out.stdout | from_yaml | union(limit_hosts.split(","))) | select("match", "^(?!\s*$).+") | list | join(",") }}' - name: Set some more facts set_fact: access_path: "{{ output_dir }}" execution_user: "{{ lookup('env', 'USER') }}" config_container: "{{ plan }}~'-config'}}" work_dir: "{{ output_dir ~ '/' ~ plan }}" - name: Run cli-grant-local-access.yaml import_playbook: /usr/share/ansible/tripleo-playbooks/cli-grant-local-access.yaml - name: Download config connection: "{{ (tripleo_target_host is defined) | ternary('ssh', 'local') }}" hosts: "{{ tripleo_target_host | default('localhost') }}" remote_user: "{{ tripleo_target_user | default(lookup('env', 'USER')) }}" gather_facts: "{{ (tripleo_target_host is defined) | ternary(true, false) }}" any_errors_fatal: true vars: plan: overcloud-0 ssh_network: ctlplane limit_hosts: '' inventory_path: null ssh_user: tripleo-admin ssh_private_key_file: /home/stack/.ssh/id_rsa tasks: - name: Download config tripleo_config_download: plan: "{{ plan }}" work_dir: "{{ work_dir }}" config_container: "{{ config_container }}" download: true - name: Generate ansible inventory tripleo_generate_ansible_inventory: plan: "{{ plan }}" work_dir: "{{ work_dir }}" ssh_network: "{{ ssh_network }}" ssh_user: "{{ ssh_user }}" ssh_private_key_file: "{{ ssh_private_key_file }}" when: not inventory_path

commit_message:
Fix TypeError when doing glance retry

'controller' arg is removed in the first retry loop,
just kick it out of loop.

Change-Id: Id592107e383d7cde3e376309c8d5b351fc60d7be
Closes-Bug: #1871744
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/92/718592/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: glance_controller = kwargs.pop('controller', 'images') controller = getattr(client, glance_controller)

commit_message:
Kibana - Add hook to delete .kibana indices

This hook is enabled for post-delete and pre-upgrade triggers.
The indices deleted by this hook are Kibana's meta indices
  - .kibana
  - .kibana_1
  - .kibana_2
  etc

This is done to get around https://github.com/elastic/kibana/issues/58388
which sometimes prevents Kibana deployments from upgrading successfully.

Change-Id: I99ccc7de20c6dadb5154e4bb714dfd302a694a78
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm-infra refs/changes/70/728570/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash {{/* Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. */}} set -ex curl -K- <<< "--user ${ELASTICSEARCH_USERNAME}:${ELASTICSEARCH_PASSWORD}" \ -X DELETE "${KIBANA_ENDPOINT}/.kibana*

subject: [Ceph] Upgrade Ceph from 14.2.8 to 14.2.9 version
revisions:

Update features guide for firewall management

This change updates our filewall management docs to reflect the current
process to manage filewall rules.

Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/07/731607/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Iptables rules are automatically deployed on overcloud nodes to open only thedeployment when needed. For example, for Zabbix monitoring system. .. code-block:: yaml ExtraFirewallRules: '301 allow zabbix': dport: 10050 proto: tcp source: 10.0.0.8 action: acceptrabbitmq rule number is 109 by default. If you want to restrain it, you could do. .. code-block:: yaml ExtraFirewallRules: '098 allow rabbit from internalapi network': dport: - 4369 - 5672 - 25672 proto: tcp source: 10.0.0.0/24 action: accept '099 drop other rabbit access': dport: - 4369 - 5672 - 25672 proto: tcp action: drop In this example, 098 and 099 are arbitrarily numbers that are smaller than the default rabbitmq rule number. To know the number of a rule, inspect the active iptables rules on an appropriate node (controller, in case of rabbitmq) .. code-block:: shelldefinition. In our case in `deployment/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-container-puppet.yaml`. .. code-block:: yaml firewall_rules: - 25673-25683 Additional information regarding the the available interface options, the role, some of the implementation details can be reviewed `here <https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-ansible/latest/roles/role-tripleo_firewall.html>`_.
deleted_lines: iptables rules are automatically deployed on overcloud nodes to open only thedeployement when is needed. For example, for Zabbix monitoring system:: ControllerExtraConfig: tripleo::firewall::firewall_rules: '301 allow zabbix': dport: 10050 proto: tcp source: 10.0.0.8 action: acceptrabbitmq rule number is 109 by default. If you want to restrain it, you can do:: ControllerExtraConfig: tripleo::firewall::firewall_rules: '098 allow rabbit from internalapi network': dport: [4369,5672,25672] proto: tcp source: 10.0.0.0/24 action: accept '099 drop other rabbit access': dport: [4369,5672,25672] proto: tcp action: drop In this example, 098 and 099 are arbitrarily chosen numbers that are smaller than the rabbitmq rule number 109. To know the number of a rule, you can inspect the iptables rule on the appropriate node (controller, in case of rabbitmq)::definition. In our case in `deployment/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-container-puppet.yaml`:: tripleo.rabbitmq.firewall_rules: The following parameters can be set for a rule: * **port**: The port associated to the rule. Deprecated by puppetlabs-firewall. * **dport**: The destination port associated to the rule. * **sport**: The source port associated to the rule. * **proto**: The protocol associated to the rule. Defaults to 'tcp' * **action**: The action policy associated to the rule. Defaults to 'accept' * **jump**: The chain to jump to. * **state**: Array of states associated to the rule. Default to ['NEW'] * **source**: The source IP address associated to the rule. * **iniface**: The network interface associated to the rule. * **chain**: The chain associated to the rule. Default to 'INPUT' * **destination**: The destination cidr associated to the rule. * **extras**: Hash of any additional parameters supported by the puppetlabs-firewall module.

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-05-15 13:27:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b04dae49960860a1231b3b5c17005688c7f38319', 'message': '[WIP] Reduce Placement calls during network deletion

Change-Id: Ifd50027911a9ca3508e80e0de9a6cc45b67006cf
Closes-Bug: #1878916
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2020-05-26 17:08:04.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/services/segments/db.py', 'neutron/services/segments/plugin.py', 'neutron/plugins/ml2/db.py', 'neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/extensions/test_segment.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2614637a697eeeafb0b9979ba2024bcd03658988', 'message': 'Delete segment RPs when network is deleted

When a network is deleted, only one Placement call per segment
is done to remove the associated (if existing) resource provider.

Before this patch, each time a subnet was deleted, the segment
resource provider was updated. When no subnets were present in the
related segment, the associated resource provider was deleted.

This optimization improves the network deletion time (see Launchpad
bug). E.g.: a network with two segments and ten subnets, the Neutron
server processing time dropped from 8.2 seconds to 4.4 seconds (note
that the poor performance was due to the modest testing environment).

Along with the segment RP optimization during the network deletion,
this patch also skips the router subnet update. Because all subnets
in the network are going to be deleted, there is no need to update
them during the network deletion process.

Change-Id: Ifd50027911a9ca3508e80e0de9a6cc45b67006cf
Closes-Bug: #1878916
(cherry picked from commit 7f40e626d6de5ec895343453b032b747c02e59f5)
'}]
commit_message:
Delete segment RPs when network is deleted

When a network is deleted, only one Placement call per segment
is done to remove the associated (if existing) resource provider.

Before this patch, each time a subnet was deleted, the segment
resource provider was updated. When no subnets were present in the
related segment, the associated resource provider was deleted.

This optimization improves the network deletion time (see Launchpad
bug). E.g.: a network with two segments and ten subnets, the Neutron
server processing time dropped from 8.2 seconds to 4.4 seconds (note
that the poor performance was due to the modest testing environment).

Along with the segment RP optimization during the network deletion,
this patch also skips the router subnet update. Because all subnets
in the network are going to be deleted, there is no need to update
them during the network deletion process.

Change-Id: Ifd50027911a9ca3508e80e0de9a6cc45b67006cf
Closes-Bug: #1878916
(cherry picked from commit 7f40e626d6de5ec895343453b032b747c02e59f5)

commit_message:
Move wheel build jobs out of project-config

This moves the wheel build jobs into openstack-zuul-jobs so we can
Depends-On changes and test here.

Note this has a dependency on a series of changes to the wheel build
jobs to support focal and arm64, which are added in changes after
this.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/731425
Change-Id: I171c94b56d1243efb83e5b457d45f23e21b3be10

commit_message:
Split ansible_limit with a colon.

Previously the --limit from tripleoclient assumed an operator would only
use a comma ','. It now converts all limit formats into a standardized format
that will always be colon ':' separated instead. This patch corrects issues
with upgrade tasks in Train and newer.

Conflicts:
    deployment/cinder/cinder-backup-pacemaker-puppet.yaml
    deployment/cinder/cinder-volume-pacemaker-puppet.yaml
    deployment/database/mysql-pacemaker-puppet.yaml
    deployment/database/redis-pacemaker-puppet.yaml
    deployment/haproxy/haproxy-pacemaker-puppet.yaml
    deployment/manila/manila-share-pacemaker-puppet.yaml
    deployment/ovn/ovn-dbs-pacemaker-puppet.yaml
    deployment/pacemaker/pacemaker-baremetal-puppet.yaml
    deployment/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-messaging-notify-pacemaker-puppet.yaml
    deployment/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-messaging-pacemaker-puppet.yaml

commit_message:
Strictly check pm_type string

Currently validation of pm_type is ambiguous because it doesn't check
trailing strings and accepts pxe_foo or redfish_baa for example.
This patch makes the validation more strict so that it fails with any
trailing items.

Change-Id: I5507942697bf4dbf599fb5135bff6560a42bfc62

commit_message:
Make user value for GlanceImageImportPlugin prevail on logic

We used to *append* image_conversion to the list of enabled Glance
import plugins when both Glance and Nova were configured to use RBD
but we should instead make user input prevail on the logic, assuming
users who customize the THT param know what they are doing and
eventually include image_conversion only when they need it.

Change-Id: I5c0788bb361323f5a0e69e22d4bd42fa3c1e06ed
(cherry picked from commit fe4253102a3ae73b125c75c9f4c51d82ddad7bbb)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/30/731030/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # We default import plugins list to 'no_op' (instead of empty list) to discern from the scenario # in which the user purposely disabled all plugins setting it to an empty list. This is useful # to automatically enable image_conversion plugin only when value is left to the default. GlanceImageImportPlugins: default: ['no_op'] force_image_conversion_plugin: - equals: [{get_param: GlanceImageImportPlugins}, ['no_op']] - force_image_conversion_plugin

subject: Python 3: fix Ansible Vault password helper
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-05-28 16:27:35.000000000', 'files': ['kayobe/tests/unit/test_kolla_ansible.py', 'kayobe/tests/unit/test_ansible.py', 'kayobe/vault.py', 'kayobe/tests/unit/test_vault.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kayobe/commit/0c5415e979daa4f4d07328563c236774fb56e513', 'message': 'Python 3: fix Ansible Vault password helper

In Python 3, the return type of subprocess.check_output is bytes by
default. It needs to be decoded to a string.

Passing universal_newlines=True to the subprocess functions results in
file objects opened in text mode, decoded using the system locale. A

Change-Id: Idb4e66aa1f2c973a956907d7986d1c05c7ce2e67
Story: 2004959
Task: 39483
(cherry picked from commit 49c3e1dab45294a6d658746b5ca1d539d7048b55)

commit_message:
Python 3: fix Ansible Vault password helper

In Python 3, the return type of subprocess.check_output is bytes by
default. It needs to be decoded to a string.

Passing universal_newlines=True to the subprocess functions results in
file objects opened in text mode, decoded using the system locale. A
unit test has also been added.

Change-Id: Idb4e66aa1f2c973a956907d7986d1c05c7ce2e67
Story: 2004959
Task: 39483
(cherry picked from commit 49c3e1dab45294a6d658746b5ca1d539d7048b55)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kayobe refs/changes/80/731580/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(vault.utils, "run_command", autospec=True) def test__get_vault_password_helper(self, mock_run): mock_run.return_value = "fake-password\n" result = vault._get_vault_password_helper() mock_run.assert_called_once_with( ["which", "kayobe-vault-password-helper"], check_output=True, universal_newlines=True) self.assertEqual('fake-password', result)

commit_message:
Include tripleo_ceph_workdir role on rgw variables override

This change includes the ceph_workdir prepare role to make
sure the ceph_rgw_config_overrides variable is set in the
same block where the task which builds the global overrides
executes.

Co-Authored-By: Giulio Fidente <gfidente@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I68690e87e678b6ad31fce37cc352083251083927
Closes-Bug: 1879938
(cherry picked from commit a9ab369898725a2a1451a8394dab2b21fb1bf5fb)

commit_message:
Add template for generation of artibtrary module

One is for resource changing module, like server start or delete,
second one is for info collection about a specific resource.

Change-Id: I78b35075111731fff2fd50837fa4e6e0c61c55a0

added_lines: ##### PLEASE READ BEFORE ##### # Module format and documentation # https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/dev_guide/developing_modules_documenting.html#module-format-and-documentation module_name: server_manage author_name: 'Happy Ansible User' author_mail: dontwrite@me.com module_short_description: "Doing something very useful" check_mode_support: True # good practice to support check_mode: # https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_checkmode.html#check-mode-dry-run module_args: optional_string: description: | This variable is set for having strin argument, for example 'action' type: str required: true default: "my_lovely_action" choices: - allowed_option1 - allowed_option1 optional_boolean: description: | This variable is set for having a boolean argument, for example whether to wait for resource creation or not type: bool required: false # may be omitted if false # and no default because not required optional_integer: description: | This variable is set for having a integer argument, for example how many seconds to wait for the resource to come alive required: true default: 60 type: int aliases: # sometimes we allow to pass the same option with different name - old_optional_integer_name - different_option_name optional_list: description: | This variable is set for having a list argument, for example files need to create with the resource type: list elements: str # type of elements of the list, can be dict, str, int, list optional_dictionary: description: | This variable is set for having a dictionary argument, for example to set environment variables or to pass more complex data to SDK required: true default: {} type: dict suboptions: suboption_1: description: suboption_1 description, what it does type: str aliases: - suboption_1_another_name suboption_2: description: suboption_2 description, what it does type: list elements: str default: []

commit_message:
Have Zuul set as many config options as possible

Zuul is able to set config options in tempest.conf for us. The
devstack plugin should only be responsible for options that depend on
other devstack options.

Change-Id: Ie459007cd477c486600e064aac31f157cb761e76

commit_message:
Add pages menu to volume backups pagination

The backups pagination was with a bug that prevents users from
access older backups when the number of backups exceeds the
page size configurated in 'API_RESULT_PAGE_SIZE' properties.

The bug was occurring because the pages displays (Next, Prev) were
not displayed in the backups page, leaving the user with only
the first page to access their backups, so the backups from other
pages are unreachable.

Was fixed this bug and also was added new buttons to access
a specific, the last and the first pages. Easing the users'
navigation through the backups pages.

Change-Id: I148634152484f9718759775b81aab3703a296ef5

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-05-27 22:08:09.000000000', 'files': ['zuul.d/ironic-jobs.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/5f24029c40688594b7f116d3e3cf23b0b48bb446', 'message': "Increase callback timeout

One of the false positives I've observed in the last
24 hours is a job where the ramdisk did not DHCP on it's

With a callback wait of 600 seconds, this means that the
deployment test job was failed moments later before the
ramdisk was fully online.

As such, lets move the timeout out a little as we're using

at this point.

Change-Id: I26bd8f2f56732be1a75518950385caeb7b439b91
"}]
commit_message:
Increase callback timeout

One of the false positives I've observed in the last
24 hours is a job where the ramdisk did not DHCP on it's
network interfaces until the 550 second of runtime mark.

With a callback wait of 600 seconds, this means that the
deployment test job was failed moments later before the
ramdisk was fully online.

As such, lets move the timeout out a little as we're using
larger ramdisks now, and we need to allow for a longer window
at this point.

Change-Id: I26bd8f2f56732be1a75518950385caeb7b439b91
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/63/731363/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: IRONIC_CALLBACK_TIMEOUT: 700

commit_message:
Install libselinux-python on Ansible control host

Certain Kolla Ansible tasks need access to the Python SELinux module. On
the Ansible control host, this module is symlinked into the
kolla-ansible virtualenv. The libselinux-python module needs to be
installed for this to succeed. Typically this is the case, but in some
environments it is not. This affects the kayobe control host bootstrap
command:

TASK [kolla-ansible : Ensure selinux Python package is linked into the
virtualenv]
fatal: [localhost]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "msg": "src file does
not exist, use \"force=yes\" if you really want to create the link:
/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/selinux", "path":
"/home/centos/kolla-venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/selinux",
"src": "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/selinux"}

This change fixes the issue by installing libselinux-python on Python 2
based systems.

Change-Id: Id1dfdfa6a597d89c42acfdd7350e16332a397083
Story: 2007703
Task: 39819
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kayobe refs/changes/21/729921/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Enable yamllint checks

- brackets
- braces
- colon
- commas
- comments
- document-end
- document-start
- empty-lines
- hyphens
- indentation
- new-line-at-end-of-file
- new-lines
- octal-values
- trailing-spaces

with corresponding code adjustment.

Also add yamllint.conf under the check.

Change-Id: Ie6251c9063c9c99ebe7c6db54c65d45d6ee7a1d4

Add helm test to cinder in openstack-support check

in the openstack-support zuul check.

commit_message:
Retire the Congress project

Recently the TC has worked on determining the criteria for when an
OpenStack project should be retired.  When there was not a PTL nominee
for the Congress project, that triggered the TC to review the project
health per [1], and the TC has determined [2] that development work on
the project has ceased.  This decision was announced in the
openstack-discuss mailing list in April 2020 [3].

This commit removes the Congress project from OpenStack infrastructure systems
as specified in the Mandatory Repository Retirement resolution [4] and detailed
in the infra manual [5].

Should interest in developing Congress as part of OpenStack revive,
please revert this commit to have the project rejoin the list of active
projects.

The community wishes to express our thanks and appreciation to all of
those who have contributed to the Congress project over the years.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/dropping-projects.html
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/latest.log.html#t2020-04-20T15:36:59
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014292.html
[4] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repository-retirement.html
[5] https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I8ac5e339700316b07b7c548f24ffc8dd83110df3
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add config-heat and config-resource options.

This add those two options. They work like their ir overcloud
conterpart.

This add the possibility to add new parameters *during*
update/upgrade/ffwd if required.

Currently adjustement has been done only to update templates.

The other limitation is that this is currently comptatible only in
infrared context and thus is skipped for upstream CI.

commit_message:
Cap jsonschema 3.2.0 as the minimal version

Previous versions of jsonschema (<3.2.0) doesn't support python 3.8 [1].
Python 3.8 is part of the victoria supported runtimes [2] so we now force
to use jsonschema version 3.2.0 to avoid issues, remove ambiguity and ensure
that everything works with python 3 in general.

[1] https://github.com/Julian/jsonschema/pull/627
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: I8e91b4b19d6d71e052061074ad927623a2892830
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-client-config refs/changes/63/730963/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: jsonschema==3.2.0

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I688a3635f99fab9c5ad9cd0f048065c64c49e516
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cliff refs/changes/13/719013/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/ussuri}

subject: Retire the Congress project
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-04-21 21:12:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/bee92f6169ef6bec335b588ab1bc54b887cdbec9', 'message': 'Retire the Congress project

Recently the TC has worked on determining the criteria for when an
OpenStack project should be retired.  When there was not a PTL nominee
for the Congress project, that triggered the TC to review the project
health per [1], and the TC has determined [2] that development work on
the project has ceased.  This decision was announced in the
openstack-discuss mailing list in April 2020 [3].

This commit retires the repository per the process for governance
removal in the Victoria cycle as specified in the Mandatory Repository
Retirement resolution [4] and detailed in the infra manual [5].

Should interest in developing Congress as part of OpenStack revive,
please revert this commit to have the project rejoin the list of active
projects.

The community wishes to express our thanks and appreciation to all of
those who have contributed to the Congress project over the years.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/dropping-projects.html
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/latest.log.html#t2020-04-20T15:36:59
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014292.html
[4] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repository-retirement.html
[5] https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: I21c9ab9820f78cf76adf11c5f0591c60f76372a8

commit_message:
Retire the Congress project

Recently the TC has worked on determining the criteria for when an
OpenStack project should be retired.  When there was not a PTL nominee
for the Congress project, that triggered the TC to review the project
health per [1], and the TC has determined [2] that development work on
the project has ceased.  This decision was announced in the
openstack-discuss mailing list in April 2020 [3].

This commit retires the repository per the process for governance
removal in the Victoria cycle as specified in the Mandatory Repository
Retirement resolution [4] and detailed in the infra manual [5].

Should interest in developing Congress as part of OpenStack revive,
please revert this commit to have the project rejoin the list of active
projects.

The community wishes to express our thanks and appreciation to all of
those who have contributed to the Congress project over the years.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/dropping-projects.html
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/latest.log.html#t2020-04-20T15:36:59
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014292.html
[4] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repository-retirement.html
[5] https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: I21c9ab9820f78cf76adf11c5f0591c60f76372a8

[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/latest.log.html#t2020-04-20T15:36:59
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014292.html
[4] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repository-retirement.html
[5] https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: I74824174861c394e75b8c733ae9bbc3c9b410268
'}]
commit_message:
Retire the Congress Tempest Plugin project

Recently the TC has worked on determining the criteria for when an
OpenStack project should be retired.  When there was not a PTL nominee
for the Congress project, that triggered the TC to review the project
health per [1], and the TC has determined [2] that development work on
the project has ceased.  This decision was announced in the
openstack-discuss mailing list in April 2020 [3].

This commit retires the repository per the process for governance
removal in the Victoria cycle as specified in the Mandatory Repository
Retirement resolution [4] and detailed in the infra manual [5].

Should interest in developing Congress as part of OpenStack revive,
please revert this commit to have the project rejoin the list of active
projects.

The community wishes to express our thanks and appreciation to all of
those who have contributed to the Congress project over the years.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/dropping-projects.html
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/latest.log.html#t2020-04-20T15:36:59
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014292.html
[4] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repository-retirement.html
[5] https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: I74824174861c394e75b8c733ae9bbc3c9b410268

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I536106e1aa71d8363a83c5014d75df4877dcdc36
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/51/722251/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: install_command = pip install -c{env:TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/ussuri} -U {opts} {packages}

commit_message:
[ocata only] Add stestr to upper constraints

Stestr dropped python 2 support with version 3.0.0, but setup.cfg was
wrongly configured in that release [1], which was fixed in version
3.0.1. Unfortunately this causes issues in python 2 as pip falsely
installs 3.0.0 as it is not restricted as python 3 only yet.

In Ocata there isn't any constraint for stestr, but grenade job on
Pike installs Tempest with using upper-constraints.txt from Ocata,
which does not cap stestr and so pip installs version 3.0.0, and
grenade job fails with the error when running stestr:

ImportError: No module named configparser

Either stestr 3.0.0 needs to be backlisted or needs to be constrained.
This patch sets the stestr===0.4.0 upper constraint and adjust other
dependencies to make the tests pass.

[1] https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/issues/292

Change-Id: I7f372e977d3c61f1a680866e10b2b7a429a99ae3

commit_message:
Fix on stestr requirements for non-py2

stestr 3.0.0 is released with drop the support of
py2 but had some issue on setup.cfg metadata to restrict
the installation on <py3 env.
- https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/issues/292

This is fixed and released in 3.0.1

Let's cap the stestr version for py2 and py3 env
also adding 3.0.0 in blacklist.

Change-Id: Id0c2371c9ba37a3f19c2e0a3c121f99b54ac9ce8

commit_message:
Fix on stestr requirements for non-py2

stestr 3.0.0 is released with drop the support of
py2 but had some issue on setup.cfg metadata to restrict
the installation on <py3 env.
- https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/issues/292

This is fixed and released in 3.0.1

Let's cap the stestr version for py2 and py3 env
also adding 3.0.0 in blacklist.

Change-Id: Id0c2371c9ba37a3f19c2e0a3c121f99b54ac9ce8
(cherry picked from commit ba693790ea2e85d4733b516d53813f62f890c0e1)

subject: Handle flavor disk mismatches when resizing
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-03-12 18:46:16.000000000', 'files': ['nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/efdcaf00e01b12ac15b938392b2f4b9e7db5eff1', 'message': "Handle flavor disk mismatches when resizing

When resizing a non-volume-backed instance, we call the
'_validate_flavor_image_nostatus' function to do a myriad of checks with
the aim of ensuring the flavor and image don't conflict. One of these
checks tests whether the flavor is requesting a smaller local disk than
the size of the image of the minimum size the image says it requires. If
this check fails, it will raise the 'FlavorDiskSmallerThanImage' or
'FlavorDiskSmallerThanMinDisk' exceptions, respectively. We currently
handle this exception in the 'create' and 'rebuild' flows but do not in
the 'resize' path. Correct this by way of adding this exception to
'INVALID_FLAVOR_IMAGE_EXCEPTIONS', a list of exceptions that can be
raised when an flavor and image conflict.

The fix for this issue also highlights another exception that can be
raised in the three code paths but is not handled by them all,
'FlavorMemoryTooSmall'. This is added to
'INVALID_FLAVOR_IMAGE_EXCEPTIONS' also.

Change-Id: Idc82ed3bcfc37220a50d9e2d552be5ab8844374a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1867077
"}]
commit_message:
Handle flavor disk mismatches when resizing

When resizing a non-volume-backed instance, we call the
'_validate_flavor_image_nostatus' function to do a myriad of checks with
the aim of ensuring the flavor and image don't conflict. One of these
checks tests whether the flavor is requesting a smaller local disk than
the size of the image of the minimum size the image says it requires. If
this check fails, it will raise the 'FlavorDiskSmallerThanImage' or
'FlavorDiskSmallerThanMinDisk' exceptions, respectively. We currently
handle this exception in the 'create' and 'rebuild' flows but do not in
the 'resize' path. Correct this by way of adding this exception to
'INVALID_FLAVOR_IMAGE_EXCEPTIONS', a list of exceptions that can be
raised when an flavor and image conflict.

The fix for this issue also highlights another exception that can be
raised in the three code paths but is not handled by them all,
'FlavorMemoryTooSmall'. This is added to
'INVALID_FLAVOR_IMAGE_EXCEPTIONS' also.

Change-Id: Idc82ed3bcfc37220a50d9e2d552be5ab8844374a
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1867077

commit_message:
wheel-cache: Use train for centos7, ussuri for centos8

Update these old references for the current releases of openstack bits
in CentOS.  As described, work-around a current bug with aarch64
builds of rabbitmq.

commit_message:
Retire the python-congressclient project

Recently the TC has worked on determining the criteria for when an
OpenStack project should be retired.  When there was not a PTL nominee
for the Congress project, that triggered the TC to review the project
health per [1], and the TC has determined [2] that development work on
the project has ceased.  This decision was announced in the
openstack-discuss mailing list in April 2020 [3].

This commit retires the repository per the process for governance
removal in the Victoria cycle as specified in the Mandatory Repository
Retirement resolution [4] and detailed in the infra manual [5].

Should interest in developing Congress as part of OpenStack revive,
please revert this commit to have the project rejoin the list of active
projects.

The community wishes to express our thanks and appreciation to all of
those who have contributed to the Congress project over the years.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/dropping-projects.html
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/latest.log.html#t2020-04-20T15:36:59
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014292.html
[4] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repository-retirement.html
[5] https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: Ib13d3325a5497064d037b007e9823609f836988d

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie56e8a77a80778e5ea4428db23b1ce085d3cfded

commit_message:
Move wheel build jobs out of project-config

Move the wheel build jobs out of project config so we can run
speculative testing (project-config is a protected repo).
requirements project has these jobs in it's gate.

The only change here is they are renamed to "wheel-cache" from
"wheel-mirror"; both to not conflict but also I think cache describes
what it does a bit better -- we put the cache on the mirror but we're
not mirroring something created externally.

See-Also: https://review.opendev.org/731401

Change-Id: Ib41607c4842dccf27b711947bf356ef5d74a1059

commit_message:
Pin stestr to 0.4.0 on ocata

This is needed for grenade jobs on stable/pike to pass
The issue was fixed on pike in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/572523/

The underlying problem is that without a constraint on stestr,
we'll get the newest version which is incompatible with the
subunit version which is constrained.

Change-Id: If6e5b398d6956059f902d776f36ca3e7cd572827

commit_message:
Fix job issues for stable branch

This includes a few fixes that will need to merge together in order to
pass.

Stop testing grenade

Grenade testing has a dependency on a newer stestr than what was
available in pike. Rather than rewrite the grenade job, since this
branch is in Extended Maintenance anyway, just drop the job.

Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

fix pep8 errors

(cherry picked from commit d92bd96ee1f20e829610511d24131f1888ddf37e)
Signed-off-by: Matthew Thode <mthode@mthode.org>

Remove legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-full

This job is failing on ocata. Too difficult to fix, so let's just remove
it.

Remove requirements-integration job

This job was a legacy job that attempted to verify each project could be
independently installed after all global-requirements had been
installed.

This job is no longer necessary since we have much better coverage with
requirements-check and other jobs that make sure the requirements are
compatible. It is also a legacy zuulv2 job, uses the long deprecated
devstack-gate, and runs with Python 2.7.

For historical reference, this was added originally to PBR back in 2013
[0] and moved to requirements in 2014 [1].

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/pbr/commit/378261a8cba818a29b7e3d33b917de5ed0751579
[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/8e073738db06086f949d2be377999356aee2d8d0

commit_message:
Add missing SYSLOG_FACILITY to JournalHandler

Without SYSLOG_FACILITY log messages from journald forwards the message
to kern.log. This seems to be default behaviour as it treats the message
as kernel message.

This option provides a proper facility to the log message and kern.log
will not be filled up anymore.

Cherry-picked from commit 5b12e66f6283962d96884e4aa3fa7db7d4e062fa
Cherry-picked from commit 82751ce2a2b913a5d107133a15960c9c6d8fd594
Change-Id: I62a32ed46a400b62ead8c1e6e64acee658e2a769
Closes-Bug: #1871840
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/57/726157/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if syslog is None: raise RuntimeError("syslog is not available on this platform") facility = _find_facility(conf.syslog_log_facility) journal = handlers.OSJournalHandler(facility=facility)

commit_message:
Add missing SYSLOG_FACILITY to JournalHandler

Without SYSLOG_FACILITY log messages from journald forwards the message
to kern.log. This seems to be default behaviour as it treats the message
as kernel message.

This option provides a proper facility to the log message and kern.log
will not be filled up anymore.

Cherry-picked from commit 5b12e66f6283962d96884e4aa3fa7db7d4e062fa
Cherry-picked from commit 82751ce2a2b913a5d107133a15960c9c6d8fd594
Cherry-picked from commit 911a45401c1292b1946c200aa0f6a98b9e246fd8
Change-Id: I62a32ed46a400b62ead8c1e6e64acee658e2a769
Closes-Bug: #1871840

commit_message:
Python 3: fix Ansible Vault password helper

In Python 3, the return type of subprocess.check_output is bytes by
default. It needs to be decoded to a string.

Passing universal_newlines=True to the subprocess functions results in
file objects opened in text mode, decoded using the system locale. A
unit test has also been added.

Change-Id: Idb4e66aa1f2c973a956907d7986d1c05c7ce2e67
Story: 2004959
Task: 39483

commit_message:
Update master for stable/ussuri

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/ussuri.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/ussuri.

Change-Id: I2faef53a799e34ec7eb898171ab1b30d40d95c03
Sem-Ver: feature

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-04-07 20:38:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.cache/commit/905c10bab8153be2de551b11098d908fa7f66df5', 'message': "Refactoring functional tests based on standard usages

Refactoring the functional tests by using the standard usages [1]
and best pratices available in the oslo.cache documentation.

The main goal of these changes is to help us to
test oslo.cache in the way that it's used in the real life.

It reduce the complexity to test new backends by using the
corresponding configuration.

These changes allow to test a new backend by:
- passing the right environment variables with the related backend to test;
- adding the corresponding zuul job that will dedicated to test this backend.
- adding the right server backend to bindep

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.cache/latest/user/usage.html

Refactoring the functional tests by using the standard usages [1]
and best pratices available in the oslo.cache documentation.

The main goal of these changes is to help us to
test oslo.cache in the way that quite close to real life usages.

To test new backend now we just need to create the associated test class
dedicated to pass backend's config fixture.

These changes allow to test a new backend by:
- passing the right config to backend by using dedicated config fixture;
- adding the zuul job dedicated to manage functional tests
  against etcd backend;
- adding the right server backend to bindep.

commit_message:
Refactoring functional tests based on standard usages

Refactoring the functional tests by using the standard usages [1]
and best pratices available in the oslo.cache documentation.

The main goal of these changes is to help us to
test oslo.cache in the way that quite close to real life usages.

To test new backend now we just need to create the associated test class
dedicated to pass backend's config fixture.

These changes allow to test a new backend by:
- passing the right config to backend by using dedicated config fixture;
- adding the zuul job dedicated to manage functional tests
  against etcd backend;
- adding the right server backend to bindep.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.cache/latest/user/usage.html

Change-Id: Iaf196d2d93225afa54e324fb830761049059926e

automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on

Recently the TC has worked on determining the criteria for when an
OpenStack project should be retired.  When there was not a PTL nominee
for the Congress project, that triggered the TC to review the project
health per [1], and the TC has determined [2] that development work on
the project has ceased.  This decision was announced in the
openstack-discuss mailing list in April 2020 [3].

This commit retires the repository per the process for governance
removal in the Victoria cycle as specified in the Mandatory Repository

projects.

The community wishes to express our thanks and appreciation to all of
those who have contributed to the Congress project over the years.

commit_message:
Retire the Congress Specs project

Recently the TC has worked on determining the criteria for when an
OpenStack project should be retired.  When there was not a PTL nominee
for the Congress project, that triggered the TC to review the project
health per [1], and the TC has determined [2] that development work on
the project has ceased.  This decision was announced in the
openstack-discuss mailing list in April 2020 [3].

This commit retires the repository per the process for governance
removal in the Victoria cycle as specified in the Mandatory Repository
Retirement resolution [4] and detailed in the infra manual [5].

Should interest in developing Congress as part of OpenStack revive,
please revert this commit to have the project rejoin the list of active
projects.

The community wishes to express our thanks and appreciation to all of
those who have contributed to the Congress project over the years.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/dropping-projects.html
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/latest.log.html#t2020-04-20T15:36:59
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014292.html
[4] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repository-retirement.html
[5] https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: Ide2a1f572f046e2d9f1bf9468556dbb39c736c0f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress-specs refs/changes/38/721738/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =============================================================================== Pull common functionality into driver superclass, including data transformation =============================================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/congress/+spec/refactor-drivers Currently, each datasource driver contains code to convert data from the API call response to the Congress data tables. This change will make it easier for a developer to add each incremental data source driver. Problem description =================== Today, it takes more code than necessary to write a data source driver. The code is also more difficult to write than necessary. Some of these API responses (like in neutron list networks) contain nested data, for example in the list of networks, each network can contain a sub-list of subnets. The driver populates a separate table for subnets and the creates a key to link between the network table and the subnet table. Proposed change =============== To generalize the driver, this change will allow a driver class to specify how to extract data from the API response, and into which table/field to put the response data. To handle the sublist conversion, the driver class will specify if a field is a sublist, and then also specify a key, so that the main table can link to the subtable. This sublist relationship will be recursive, so that a sublist can also contain another sublist. Alternatives ------------ None Policy ------ None Policy Actions -------------- None Data Sources ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- This change will have an effect as soon as it is merged, but Congress should behave exactly as it did without the change. Developer impact ---------------- The new refactoring will change how programmers write datasource drivers. The new way should be easier, require less code, and be less bug prone. To take advantage of the new refactoring, we'll need to rewrite the existing drivers, but this need not happen at the same time as writing the new datasource driver superclass. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- ayip Work items ---------- 1) Write new superclass. 2) Rewrite Nova driver. 3) Rewrite Neutron driver. 4) Rewrite Keystone driver. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests for superclass, and modify existing test cases for individual drivers. Documentation impact ==================== This change will include new documentation for how to use the new datasource driver superclass. References ========== None

commit_message:
Policy History

PolicyEnigne shows up-to-data rows matching to policy rules. In some
cases, admin want to know the history of rows becasue of audit.

This spec proposes a functionality that PolicyEnigne outputs rows
data with someway and admin can read it lator.

blueprint policy-history

Change-Id: I7b156c0aa446c10127f999b62dd8f8c379b37636
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress-specs refs/changes/60/303960/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============== Policy History ============== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/congress/+spec/policy-history Problem description =================== Currently, Policy Engine keeps up-to-date rows matched to policy rules. It's easy for admin to check what is violated to rules now and what Congress will react the rows. However, admin want to keep track of the changed rows or row's snapshot in case of rules are for audit. Proposed change =============== This proposes a functionality to enable admin to see row's history. If admin needs the history, he/she sets a history flag of rule to True and PolicyEngine writes changed rows or snapshot out. And then the admin can read the history if needed. This BP focuses on a history of policy rule's row. The one of most important requirements for history is to record and store entire history, not to quickly respond a request for reading it. There are a lot of well developeed data store system in the world, OpenStack Swift or elasticsearch as well as local files. Congress should use these great outer systems to record history, so this change outputs history to outer system and admin reads history from the system on demand. So, Congress will only be in charge of output history with its specified format, and the outer system will be in charge of storing the history. Additionaly, the means to record should have a selectability depended on what data store admin wants to use. Each company or admin usually has a existing data store for thier audit process. Hence, admin could choose the means to record by their demands. Alternatives ------------ Congress stores all history in itself, and admin can check the history through Congress's API. The good points are all operations related to policy rule including history are under the controll by Congress and admin can fetch all data related to Congress by API. The down side is Congress has to take care of storing history. Congress, Governance as a Service, has responsibilities for defining policy, reacting or enforcing it. But storing history in itself requires Congress different abilities. Policy ------ N/A Policy actions -------------- Calculated rows of policy rule are recorded as history if the history flag is True. Rows matching to reactive policy rule are recorded too.On the other hand, rows matching to proactive policy enforcement don't need to be recorded since the policy doesn't exist in anywhere and the rows in API response is not real policy rows. Data sources ------------ N/A Data model impact ----------------- To write out history to other system, this change introduces a new abstract subclass of dse_service, named history_service. History_service is in charge of receiving history data and output every history data to outer systems. All steps from calculating policy rule to recording history into outer systems are following: 1. PolicyEngine calculates row of policy rule using datasource rows 2. PolicyEngine publishes the change of the row if the history flag for the rule is True 3. History_service receives the change from PolicyEngine 4. History_service writes out the change as history with appropriate formats into an outer system As described in Proposed change section, the outer system varies. So history_service adopts a plugin style for its implementation. History_service class is a base class for recording history and doesn't have any real implementation. If admin wants to record history into a regular file, file_history_service is used for history which is subclass of history_service. If admin wants to do into Swift's objects, swift_history_service is used for it. REST API impact --------------- This adds a new field for history in Create Policy Rule API and Read Policy Rule API. * Create Policy Rule API The default value for history is False * API Schema POST /v1/policy/<policy name>/rules * Request Body .. code-block:: javascript { "name": <rule name>, "rule": <rule string>, "history": <True or False> "comment": <comment> } * Response Body .. code-block:: javascript { "name": <rule name>, "rule": <rule string>, "history": <True or False> "comment": <comment> } * Read Policy Rule API * API Schema POST /v1/policy/<policy name>/rules/<rule id> * Response Body .. code-block:: javascript { "name": <rule name>, "rule": <rule string>, "history": <True or False>, "comment": <comment> } Security impact --------------- The history has some information related to policy rules. But Congress doesn't store the history in itself since outer systems stores all history, so there is no impact for Congress. Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- As described in API impact secssion, admin who writes and sets up policy rule can choose whether the rule outputs its history or not. However, any history isn't stored in any outer system unless Congress is deployed with history_service. Performance impact ------------------ Storing history into outer systems could causes a performance issue if the history_service and PolicyEngine run on same dse_node, since low latency for storing data suspends PolicyEngine to calculate rules or to poll data. On the other hands, the new architecture allows operators to deploy each service in different node and host. It will reduce a performance issue described above. Other deployer impact --------------------- N/A Developer impact ---------------- N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: muroi-masahito Other contributors: muroi-masahito Work items ---------- 0. implementing history_service class 1. implementing at least one subclass of history_service for real depolyment of history_service 2. adding a history flag column in Congress DB schema Dependencies ============ * the new distributed architecture Testing ======= * Add unit tests related to the functionality * Add Tempest tests to store history Documentation impact ==================== * API reference will be updated * How to work history_service References ========== N/A

commit_message:
Cap jsonschema 3.2.0 as the minimal version

Previous versions of jsonschema (<3.2.0) doesn't support python 3.8 [1].
Python 3.8 is part of the victoria supported runtimes [2] so we now force
to use jsonschema version 3.2.0 to avoid issues, remove ambiguity and ensure
that everything works with python 3 in general.

[1] https://github.com/Julian/jsonschema/pull/627
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: I24655eef016933d1607a8c7764c91073ff5cbdaf

commit_message:
Remove sphinx restriction on python version

We are now full python 3 and higher or equal to python 3.6 so we don't need
to keep this restriction. Also it will fix requirements-check jobs.

Change-Id: I1c4c3081d6ebdcadb656caf5973b5b11333ad9f6

commit_message:
Remove translation sections from setup.cfg

These translation sections are not needed anymore, Babel can
generate translation files without them.

Change-Id: I3796011ca54540b5eb75d1e223c1662a859fe52d

commit_message:
Add py38 package metadata

Now that we are running the Victoria tests that include a
voting py38, we can now add the Python 3.8 metadata to the
package information to reflect that support.

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

We can now use the standard library mock library instead of the third
party one previously needed for py27 compatibility.

Change-Id: I18017068324e929c5b8df18ac0c9f9aa6c6328ff
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Return informative HTTP errors on DB error

Right now some oslo_db errors get converted into HTTP 500
errors without any further information. This patch makes sure
the oslo_db errors are wrapped in congress errors that then
gets interpreted properly be api/webservice code to return
informative HTTP errors.

Closes-Bug: 1747571

Change-Id: Iaff87dcbc1fd3172dca6f95ab7e598da8358cb20

commit_message:
CI jobs use latest openstack code from git

Stop overriding the LIBS_FROM_GIT variable in job config
so that all required projects are loaded from top of tree
rather than most recent release.

Change-Id: I1d128c4dc5dd1d1bd4945ca0a434fa5085759749

commit_message:
Broadcast policy sync to PEs on datasource create

This way the PEs will initialize the datasource schema and allow
rule creation using named arguments. Applies to both the single PE
distributed case as well as the replicated PE case.

Task previously kept as TODO.

Change-Id: I31137229ad72315549a9a1dc3655cc9a5aabe890

commit_message:
Replace file() with open() for Python 3 compatibility

The built-in named 'file' has been removed since Python 3.0 [1]
This patch replaces it by 'open' which is the same under Python 2 and 3.

[1] https://docs.python.org/release/3.0/whatsnew/3.0.html#builtins

Change-Id: I44d1625f44d46d1a7e9ee9109544bd5bec97c674

added_lines: from oslo_log import log as loggingLOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def check_service_data_against_congress_table( self, table_name, service_data_fetch_func): table_schema = ( self.os_admin.congress_client.show_datasource_table_schema( self.datasource_id, table_name)['columns']) table_id_col = next(i for i, c in enumerate(table_schema) if c['name'] == 'id') def _check_data(): # Fetch data each time, because test may before service is ready service_data = service_data_fetch_func() service_data_map = {} for data_item in service_data: service_data_map[data_item['id']] = data_item table_data = ( self.os_admin.congress_client.list_datasource_rows( self.datasource_id, table_name)['results']) LOG.debug('Congress %s table: %s', table_name, table_data) for row in table_data: try: service_item = service_data_map[row['data'][table_id_col]] except KeyError: return False for index in range(len(table_schema)): if (str(row['data'][index]) != str(service_item[table_schema[index]['name']])): return False return True if not test_utils.call_until_true( func=_check_data, duration=100, sleep_for=4): raise exceptions.TimeoutException("Data did not converge in time " "or failure in server") table_name = 'images' service_data_fetch_func = lambda: self.glancev2.list_images()['images'] self.check_service_data_against_congress_table( table_name, service_data_fetch_func)
deleted_lines: image_schema = ( self.os_admin.congress_client.show_datasource_table_schema( self.datasource_id, 'images')['columns']) image_id_col = next(i for i, c in enumerate(image_schema) if c['name'] == 'id') def _check_data_table_glancev2_images(): # Fetch data from glance each time, because this test may start # before glance has all the users. images = self.glancev2.list_images()['images'] image_map = {} for image in images: image_map[image['id']] = image results = ( self.os_admin.congress_client.list_datasource_rows( self.datasource_id, 'images')) for row in results['results']: try: image_row = image_map[row['data'][image_id_col]] except KeyError: return False for index in range(len(image_schema)): # glancev2 doesn't return kernel_id/ramdisk_id if # it isn't present... if ((image_schema[index]['name'] == 'kernel_id' and 'kernel_id' not in row['data']) or (image_schema[index]['name'] == 'ramdisk_id' and 'ramdisk_id' not in row['data'])): continue # FIXME(arosen): congress-server should retain the type # but doesn't today. if (str(row['data'][index]) != str(image_row[image_schema[index]['name']])): return False return True if not test_utils.call_until_true( func=_check_data_table_glancev2_images, duration=100, sleep_for=4): raise exceptions.TimeoutException("Data did not converge in time " "or failure in server")

The Monasca Alarm Datasource enables to receive alarms using the

Alarms are set out of band in Monasca and the Monasca Alarm

commit_message:
Monasca Alarm Datasource

The Monasca Alarm Datasource enables to receive alarms using the
push method in Congress to respond to conditions set as alarms
in Monasca.
Alarms are set out of band in Monasca and the Monasca Alarm
datasource processes and stores them into a table.

Change-Id: I2f74f20ca64f842c3f6dc5be5c33572c1b4aebc9
Co-Authored-By: Jonathan Leonard <jonathan@mustwin.com>

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # from __future__ import print_function from __future__ import division from __future__ import absolute_import from oslo_log import log as logging import six from congress.datasources import datasource_driver LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def d6service(name, keys, inbox, datapath, args): """This method is called by d6cage to create a dataservice instance.""" return MonascaEventDriver(name, keys, inbox, datapath, args) class MonascaAlarmDriver(datasource_driver.PushedDataSourceDriver): """A DataSource Driver for Monasca webhook notifications. request body: { "alarm_id": "01234567-89ab-cdef-0123-456789abcdef", "alarm_definition_id": "01234567-89ab-cdef-0123-456789abcdef", "alarm_name": "CPU Usage", "alarm_timestamp": 1458915757, "state": "ALARM", "old_state", "OK", "message", "Alarms when CPU usage is high", "tenant_id": "ed209deadbeef3709a2ab8eb8ea7996c", "metrics": [ { "name": "cpu.system_perc", "dimensions": { "key": "value", ..... }, }, ..... ] } """ value_trans = {'translation-type': 'VALUE'} """Flattening the metric dimensions with the metric name reduces the schema to 2 tables instead of 3""" def flatten_metrics(metrics): flatten = {} for metric in metrics: name_prefix = metric['name'] + '.' dimensions = metric.pop('dimensions') for k, v in dimensions.items(): flatten[name_prefix + k] = v return flatten def widen_event(event): return [event] metrics_translator = { 'translation-type': 'VDICT', 'table-name': 'metric_dimensions', 'parent-key': 'alarm_id', 'key-col': 'key', 'val-col': 'value', 'objects-extract-fn': flatten_metrics, 'translator': value_trans } events_translator = { 'translation-type': 'HDICT', 'table-name': 'events', 'selector-type': 'DICT_SELECTOR', 'objects-extract-fn': widen_event, 'field-translators': ({'fieldname': 'alarm_id', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'alarm_definition_id', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'alarm_name', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'alarm_description', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'alarm_timestamp', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'state', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'old_state', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'metrics', 'translator': metrics_translator}, {'fieldname': 'tenant_id', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'message', 'translator': value_trans}, {'fieldname': 'hostname', 'translator': value_trans},) } TRANSLATORS = [events_translator] def __init__(self, name='', keys='', inbox=None, datapath=None, args=None): super(MonascaAlarmDriver, self).__init__(name, keys, inbox, datapath, args) @staticmethod def get_datasource_info(): result = {} result['id'] = 'monasca_event' result['description'] = ('Datasource driver that interfaces with ' 'Monasca webhook alarm notifications.') result['config'] = {} return result

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from multiprocessing import Pool import random import string # import time from oslo_log import log as logging from tempest import config # from tempest.lib import exceptions from tempest import test # from congress_tempest_tests.tests.scenario import helper from congress_tempest_tests.tests.scenario import manager_congress CONF = config.CONF LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class TestCongressHAHT(manager_congress.ScenarioPolicyBase): @classmethod def skip_checks(cls): super(TestCongressHAHT, cls).skip_checks() if not (CONF.network.project_networks_reachable or CONF.network.public_network_id): msg = ('Either project_networks_reachable must be "true", or ' 'public_network_id must be defined.') cls.enabled = False raise cls.skipException(msg) def setUp(self): super(TestCongressHAHT, self).setUp() self.keypairs = {} self.servers = [] def _create_random_policy(self): policy_name = "nova_%s" % ''.join(random.choice(string.lowercase) for x in range(10)) body = {"name": policy_name} resp = self.admin_manager.congress_client.create_policy(body) self.addCleanup(self.admin_manager.congress_client.delete_policy, resp['id']) return resp['name'] def _create_policy_rule(self, policy_name, rule, rule_name=None, comment=None): body = {'rule': rule} if rule_name: body['name'] = rule_name if comment: body['comment'] = comment client = self.admin_manager.congress_client response = client.create_policy_rule(policy_name, body) if response: self.addCleanup(client.delete_policy_rule, policy_name, response['id']) return response else: raise Exception('Failed to create policy rule (%s, %s)' % (policy_name, rule)) @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_duplicate_policy_rules(self): policyname = self._create_random_policy() self.addCleanup( self.admin_manager.congress_client.delete_policy, policyname) p = Pool(5) body = {"rule": "p(x) :- q(x)"} results = p.map(self.admin_manager.congress_client.create_policy_rule, [(policyname, body)] * 5) LOG.debug("EKCS: " + str(results))# # self.assertTrue(len(resp_body['results']) == 1) resp, resp_body = \ self.admin_manager.congress_client.list_policy_rules(policyname) LOG.debug("EKCS: " + str(resp_body))# self.assertTrue(len(resp_body['results']) == 1)

commit_message:
Add missing SYSLOG_FACILITY to JournalHandler

Without SYSLOG_FACILITY log messages from journald forwards the message
to kern.log. This seems to be default behaviour as it treats the message
as kernel message.

This option provides a proper facility to the log message and kern.log
will not be filled up anymore.

Cherry-picked from commit 5b12e66f6283962d96884e4aa3fa7db7d4e062fa
Change-Id: I62a32ed46a400b62ead8c1e6e64acee658e2a769
Closes-Bug: #1871840
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/56/726156/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if syslog is None: raise RuntimeError("syslog is not available on this platform") facility = _find_facility(conf.syslog_log_facility) journal = handlers.OSJournalHandler(facility=facility)

subject: Retire the Congress Dashboard project
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-04-21 21:32:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress-dashboard/commit/5deaa507be4afa80fa60dd89487ade5013419a27', 'message': 'Retire the Congress Dashboard project

Recently the TC has worked on determining the criteria for when an
OpenStack project should be retired.  When there was not a PTL nominee
for the Congress project, that triggered the TC to review the project
health per [1], and the TC has determined [2] that development work on
the project has ceased.  This decision was announced in the
openstack-discuss mailing list in April 2020 [3].

This commit retires the repository per the process for governance
removal in the Victoria cycle as specified in the Mandatory Repository
Retirement resolution [4] and detailed in the infra manual [5].

Should interest in developing Congress as part of OpenStack revive,
please revert this commit to have the project rejoin the list of active
projects.

The community wishes to express our thanks and appreciation to all of
those who have contributed to the Congress project over the years.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/dropping-projects.html
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/latest.log.html#t2020-04-20T15:36:59
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014292.html

[5] https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

commit_message:
Retire the Congress Dashboard project

Recently the TC has worked on determining the criteria for when an
OpenStack project should be retired.  When there was not a PTL nominee
for the Congress project, that triggered the TC to review the project
health per [1], and the TC has determined [2] that development work on
the project has ceased.  This decision was announced in the
openstack-discuss mailing list in April 2020 [3].

This commit retires the repository per the process for governance
removal in the Victoria cycle as specified in the Mandatory Repository
Retirement resolution [4] and detailed in the infra manual [5].

Should interest in developing Congress as part of OpenStack revive,
please revert this commit to have the project rejoin the list of active
projects.

The community wishes to express our thanks and appreciation to all of
those who have contributed to the Congress project over the years.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/dropping-projects.html
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-tc/latest.log.html#t2020-04-20T15:36:59
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-April/014292.html
[4] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20190711-mandatory-repository-retirement.html
[5] https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: I8026809e82c6aff8b64932a931229a08c6360629

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: If990db865cd579cecc0cdb6d0c075112a55fa1b6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress-dashboard refs/changes/47/722247/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: -c{env:TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/ussuri}

commit_message:
Remove use of deprecated config options for volume API selection

Tempest has moved the Volume APIs testing to v3 as default and can be run
under v2 API via catalog_type.
- https://review.opendev.org/#/q/topic:volume-default-testing-v3+(status:open+OR+status:merged)

Below config options were deprecated since Rocky and now Tempest is going
to remove those (Needed-By patch):
    * ``CONF.volume-feature-enabled.api_v2``
    * ``CONF.volume-feature-enabled.api_v3``

Change-Id: I1ab737801b13f0c7a2e079ca0a1b43831ece1742
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698754/

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2018 NEC, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_serialization import jsonutils as json from tempest.lib.common import rest_client class TackerClient(rest_client.RestClient): vnfs = '/v1.0/vnfs.json' vnfds = '/v1.0/vnfds.json' vnfd_path = '/v1.0/vnfds/%s.json' def _add_params_to_url(self, url, params): for key in params: url = url + '?{param_name}={param_value}'.format( param_name=key, param_value=params[key]) return url def _resp_helper(self, resp, body=None): if body: body = json.loads(body) return rest_client.ResponseBody(resp, body) def list_vnfds(self): resp, body = self.get(self.vnfds) return self._resp_helper(resp, body) def create_vnfd(self, body): body = json.dumps(body) resp, body = self.post(self.vnfds, body=body) return self._resp_helper(resp, body) def show_vnfd(self, vnfd_id): resp, body = self.get(self.vnfd_path % vnfd_id) return self._resp_helper(resp, body) def delete_vnfd(self, vnfd_id): resp, body = self.delete(self.vnfd_path % vnfd_id) return self._resp_helper(resp, body)

commit_message:
Update master for stable/ussuri

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/ussuri.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/ussuri.

Change-Id: I634d8ebfd63cff4faad3c548d53732561c956d1f
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Remove column reference in vitrage driver test rule

The creation of rule with column reference needs to wait for datasource
table schema to propagate, leading to occassional time-out errors.
Because the use of column reference is unnecessary for these tests,
replace with rule without column reference.

Change-Id: I3da9f40aaaa3c2dc210b14d0f775951302f5565d

commit_message:
Gate fix for error randomly generating at neutron-port table

Gate has been randomly failing around neutron ports table test [1][2].
This is probably because status of floating ip network which is 'N/A'
until it is attached, which causes ambiguity in gate. As any state
other then 'ACTIVE', 'DOWN', 'BUILD', 'ERROR' will be converted to
'OTHER' in congress neutronv2 driver[3]. Hence when its N/A test fails.

So there must be seperate test for testing neutronv2.floating_ips table
with the neutron floating_ips api's.

This commit simply skips comparing data around floating_ip row in ports
table.

commit_message:
Set default tempest_test_timeout for ironic-base

The configuration of this job is shared between all jobs
that have `parent: ironic-base` so we don't need to set
timeouts in other jobs.

Change-Id: I49f8d7c4a8d33d38f430a6325a58e1a0af8411b1

added_lines: tempest_test_timeout: 2400

generate translation files without them.

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I435d32bf034040325128f2b5275d907062d63351
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-05-15 13:34:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/9856933db19d423e5bb3254f5d87163c1032815a', 'message': 'Raise the JSON RPC connection timeout to 2 minutes

Apparently, 15 seconds is easily exceeded in our CI. Raise to 2 mins
for a more conservative default (can be changed via ironic.conf)

Change-Id: Ic155943f234505a34cfea273fd00441a9a0942f5
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2020-05-15 13:43:22.000000000', 'files': ['ironic/conf/json_rpc.py', 'releasenotes/notes/json-rpc-timeout-ac30eea164b3a294.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/38137e6c40c73ba5266874cfdec3caab0196b6d6', 'message': 'Raise the JSON RPC connection timeout to 2 minutes and disable retries

Apparently, 15 seconds is easily exceeded in our CI. Raise to 2 mins
for a more conservative default (can be changed via ironic.conf)

Retries can be risky since a running request may end up being retried
if it takes really long. Also with 2 retries it may take 6 minutes
to give up on a failed server, which will cause timeouts on the caller
side anyway. Remove retries, while keeping a way to add them.

Change-Id: Ic155943f234505a34cfea273fd00441a9a0942f5
'}]
commit_message:
Raise the JSON RPC connection timeout to 2 minutes and disable retries

Apparently, 15 seconds is easily exceeded in our CI. Raise to 2 mins
for a more conservative default (can be changed via ironic.conf)

Retries can be risky since a running request may end up being retried
if it takes really long. Also with 2 retries it may take 6 minutes
to give up on a failed server, which will cause timeouts on the caller
side anyway. Remove retries, while keeping a way to add them.

Change-Id: Ic155943f234505a34cfea273fd00441a9a0942f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/45/728445/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: conf.set_default('timeout', 120, group='json_rpc')

commit_message:
Remove support for CentOS 7 and Python 2

* Always use Python 3
* Drop code paths for CentOS 7
* Drop support for Yum
* Remove support for host NTP daemon, always use chrony
* Switch references from 'yum_install_epel' to 'dnf_install_epel'
* Remove overcloud host image workaround for tagged VLAN admin network
* Remove the kayobe.utils.yum_install function, which is unused

Change-Id: I368f6edafed9779658798fc342116b4c1b3ffd48
Story: 2006574
Task: 39481
